Literature Review:
The study of ocean circulation and connectivity between the Arctic and Subpolar North Atlantic Oceans has been significantly advanced through the use of nuclear reprocessing tracers. These tracers, particularly anthropogenic radionuclides such as 137Cs, 129I, and 236U, have provided invaluable insights into the complex dynamics of oceanic flow and mixing processes. The release of these radionuclides from European nuclear fuel reprocessing plants has allowed researchers to track their movement through the ocean, offering a unique perspective on water circulation patterns, mixing, ventilation, and deep-water formation. 

Historically, 137Cs was one of the first radionuclides used to study ocean circulation. Its presence in the Arctic Ocean was initially documented in the 1970s, providing early evidence of the northward transport of surface waters from the North Atlantic into the Arctic (Aarkrog et al., 1983). The distribution of 137Cs revealed significant insights into the pathways and timescales of water mass movement, highlighting the role of the Arctic Ocean as a conduit for water exchange between the Atlantic and Pacific Oceans (Livingston et al., 1984). 

In recent years, the focus has shifted towards the use of 129I and 236U as tracers. These radionuclides are particularly valuable due to their long half-lives and conservative behavior in the marine environment, which allow for the study of long-term circulation patterns. The development of accelerator mass spectrometry has enabled the precise measurement of these tracers, facilitating more detailed investigations into oceanic processes (Edmonds et al., 2001). 

The use of 129I as a tracer has been instrumental in understanding the connectivity between the Arctic and North Atlantic Oceans. Studies have shown that 129I released from European reprocessing plants is transported northward into the Arctic Ocean, where it is subsequently distributed throughout the water column and eventually exits into the North Atlantic (Smith et al., 2005). This movement is indicative of the complex interplay between surface and deep-water currents, as well as the influence of atmospheric and oceanic conditions on tracer distribution. 

Similarly, 236U has been used to trace the pathways of water masses in the Arctic and North Atlantic Oceans. Research has demonstrated that 236U is transported along similar routes as 129I, providing complementary data on the circulation and mixing processes in these regions (Karcher et al., 2012). The combination of 129I and 236U data has allowed for a more comprehensive understanding of the temporal and spatial variability of ocean circulation, as well as the factors driving these changes. 

The integration of tracer data with numerical models, such as the North Atlantic–Arctic Ocean–Sea Ice Model (NAOSIM), has further enhanced our understanding of ocean circulation. These models simulate the movement of water masses and tracers, providing a framework for interpreting observational data and predicting future changes in ocean circulation (Karcher et al., 2003). The use of transit time distributions in these models has been particularly effective in accounting for mixing processes and improving the accuracy of circulation estimates (Rhein et al., 2011). 

Overall, the use of nuclear reprocessing tracers has significantly advanced our understanding of the connectivity between the Arctic and Subpolar North Atlantic Oceans. These tracers have provided critical insights into the mechanisms driving ocean circulation, the pathways of water mass movement, and the timescales of these processes. As climate change continues to impact the global ocean, the information gained from tracer studies will be essential for predicting future changes in ocean circulation and their implications for global climate and thermohaline circulation.
